challenge_feedback: Not really, for example "puzzle captchas" are more tolerable than this, but this is still way better than Google's "Click on an image and wait for ages until the next one appears"
No, I would prefer the Image-Captcha
general_feedback: The centered requires much effort to read the text.

challenge_feedback: I strongly prefer image-based challenges because it requires less work
general_feedback: You may need a better sentence tokenizer -- one of the sentences was cut short likely because of the periods in the "L.B.J." acronym.

challenge_feedback: Depends massively on the amount of answers needed to complete the captcha, but if it's only one answer then yes.
For me it's okay, but in general not because you need good knowledge in the language to complete the captcha.
Yes, but with a possible choice of language.

general_feedback: There should be an option to indicate that one does not know the meaning of a word in a concrete context. If I would chose to select the lowest score for such cases, you won't be able to distinguish between real "lowest score" answers and such where I simply did not understand the meaning in one of the sentences.

I didnâ€™t understand the first two sentences, so my rating was basically a random guess. If implemented, it should make sure that a proficient speaker understands the sentences. Also, I found it annoying that the same 2nd sentence was repeated every time.

challenge_feedback: Ideally if I was able to discern the meaning of the sentences I would prefer it over image CAPTCHAs, however I struggled with the sentences given in the test because I did not know the meaning of most usages and had to guess.
